text:
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow.

He was an old man who fished alone in a skiff in the Gulf Stream and he had gone eighty-four days now without taking a fish. In the first forty days a boy had been with him. But after forty days without a fish the boy’s parents had told him that the old man was now definitely and finally ‘salao’, which is the worst form of unlucky, and the boy had gone at their orders in another boat which caught three good fish the first week.

The boy was sad to see the old man come in each day with his skiff empty and he always went down to help him carry either the coiled lines or the gaff and harpoon and the sail that was furled around the mast. The sail was patched with flour sacks and, furled, it looked like the flag of permanent defeat.

A1. Simple Factual (2 marks)
Complete the following sentences:
(i) The old man had gone _______ days without catching a fish.
(ii) The boy's parents called the old man _______, which means unlucky.

A2. Complex Factual (2 marks)
Why did the boy, Manolin, stop fishing with the old man, Santiago?

A3. Vocabulary (2 marks)
Find words from the passage which mean: (i) A small boat (ii) Rolled and tied up

A4. Grammar (2 marks)
Do as directed:
(i) The boy was sad. (Make it exclamatory)
(ii) He had gone eighty-four days now without taking a fish. (Identify the tense)

A5. Personal Response (2 marks)
The boy helped the old man even though he wasn't fishing with him. What does this tell you about their relationship?
answer:
A1.
(i) The old man had gone eighty-four days without catching a fish.
(ii) The boy's parents called the old man salao, which means unlucky.

A2. The boy stopped fishing with the old man because after forty days of catching no fish, the boy's parents told him that the old man was 'salao' (the worst form of unlucky) and ordered him to go in another, more successful boat.

A3. (i) skiff (ii) furled

A4.
(i) How sad the boy was!
(ii) Past Perfect Tense.

A5. This shows that their relationship was based on deep affection and respect, not just work. The boy, Manolin, truly cared for the old man, Santiago. He looked up to him as a mentor and friend, and his loyalty and love for Santiago did not diminish even when he was forced to fish in another boat.

text:
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow.

He was a very big fish, silver and fresh and his sides were dark purple and in the sun the stripes on his sides showed wide and a light lavender. The old man dropped his lines and put his foot on the line that held the great fish. He had been pulled down tight on his bow and his face was in the cut slice of dolphin and he could not move.

“I wish the boy was here,” he said aloud.

He was fast to a very big fish and he could not see him. The fish was pulling the skiff steadily. The old man knew that the fish was not frightened. The old man could not raise the fish. It was the fish that was towing the boat.

“He has his plan and I have mine,” he said. He was a great fish and he must be worth a lot of money, he thought. But he did not think of the money. He thought of him with resolution and high dignity.

A1. Simple Factual (2 marks)
Describe the appearance of the great fish.

A2. Complex Factual (2 marks)
Why did the old man wish for the boy to be with him?

A3. Vocabulary (2 marks)
Find words from the passage that mean: (i) Constantly or without stopping (ii) A firm decision to do something

A4. Grammar (2 marks)
Do as directed:
(i) He was a great fish. (Add a question tag)
(ii) The fish was pulling the skiff steadily. (Change the voice)

A5. Personal Response (2 marks)
The old man respected the fish he was trying to catch. What does this show about him?
answer:
A1. The fish was very big and silver. Its sides were dark purple with wide, light lavender stripes that showed in the sun.

A2. The old man wished for the boy to be with him because he was alone and tied to a very large and powerful fish that was pulling his boat. He needed help and also missed the boy's companionship during this immense struggle.

A3. (i) steadily (ii) resolution

A4.
(i) He was a great fish, wasn't he?
(ii) The skiff was being pulled steadily by the fish.

A5. This shows that the old man was not just a fisherman, but a true sportsman with a deep connection to nature. He saw the fish not just as a prize, but as a noble and worthy adversary. His respect for the fish's strength and dignity reveals his own nobility and his profound understanding of the sea.

text:
Language Study (Grammar)

Do as directed:

1. The boy was sad to see the old man come in each day. (Identify the infinitive)

2. It looked like the flag of permanent defeat. (Identify the figure of speech)

3. The old man was now definitely and finally ‘salao’. (Identify the adverbs)

4. He had gone eighty-four days now without taking a fish. (Rewrite as a simple sentence)
answer:
1. The infinitive is 'to see'.

2. Simile: The patched sail is directly compared to a 'flag of permanent defeat' using the word 'like'.

3. The adverbs are: now, definitely, finally.

4. Despite fishing for eighty-four days, he had not taken a fish.

text: Explain the theme of 'triumph and defeat' as seen in 'The Old Man and the Sea'.
answer: The theme of 'triumph and defeat' is central to the story. The old man, Santiago, achieves a great triumph by catching the giant marlin after a heroic struggle, proving his skill and endurance. However, this victory is followed by a crushing defeat when sharks devour the fish on his journey home, leaving him with only a skeleton. Yet, the story suggests that true victory lies not in the material prize but in the struggle itself. Though he is defeated by the sharks, Santiago is not destroyed in spirit. He has proven his strength to himself and earned the respect of the boy, which is a deeper, more meaningful triumph.

text:
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow.

One dollar and eighty-seven cents. That was all. And sixty cents of it was in pennies. Pennies saved one and two at a time by bulldozing the grocer and the vegetable man and the butcher until one’s cheeks burned with the silent imputation of parsimony that such close dealing implied. Three times Della counted it. One dollar and eighty-seven cents. And the next day would be Christmas.

There was clearly nothing to do but flop down on the shabby little couch and howl. So Della did it. Which instigates the moral reflection that life is made up of sobs, sniffles, and smiles, with sniffles predominating.

Della finished her cry and attended to her cheeks with the powder rag. She stood by the window and looked out dully at a grey cat walking a grey fence in a grey backyard. Tomorrow would be Christmas Day, and she had only $1.87 with which to buy Jim a present.

A1. Simple Factual (2 marks)
Complete the following sentences:
(i) The total amount of money Della had was _______.
(ii) The next day was _______.

A2. Complex Factual (2 marks)
Why was Della feeling sad and helpless?

A3. Vocabulary (2 marks)
Find words from the passage that mean: (i) An accusation or suggestion (ii) Being extremely careful with money

A4. Grammar (2 marks)
Do as directed:
(i) She had only $1.87. (Make it negative without changing the meaning)
(ii) Della finished her cry. (Identify the tense)

A5. Personal Response (2 marks)
Della saved money by 'bulldozing' the shopkeepers. Do you think this is an acceptable way to save money?
answer:
A1.
(i) The total amount of money Della had was one dollar and eighty-seven cents.
(ii) The next day was Christmas.

A2. Della was feeling sad and helpless because it was Christmas Eve and she had only $1.87, which was not enough to buy a worthy Christmas present for her beloved husband, Jim.

A3. (i) imputation (ii) parsimony

A4.
(i) She had no more than $1.87.
(ii) Simple Past Tense.

A5. No, I don't think this is an acceptable way. While saving money is good, 'bulldozing' or haggling very aggressively can be disrespectful to the hard work of the shopkeepers. It's important to be fair and value the goods and services provided by others, rather than trying to save money at their expense.

text:
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow.

Now, there were two possessions of the James Dillingham Youngs in which they both took a mighty pride. One was Jim’s gold watch that had been his father’s and his grandfather’s. The other was Della’s hair. Had the queen of Sheba lived in the flat across the airshaft, Della would have let her hair hang out the window some day to dry just to depreciate Her Majesty’s jewels and gifts.

So now Della’s beautiful hair fell about her rippling and shining like a cascade of brown waters. It reached below her knee and made itself almost a garment for her. And then she did it up again nervously and quickly. Once she faltered for a minute and stood still while a tear or two splashed on the worn red carpet.

On went her old brown jacket; on went her old brown hat. With a whirl of skirts and with the brilliant sparkle still in her eyes, she fluttered out the door and down the stairs to the street.

A1. Simple Factual (2 marks)
What were the two prized possessions of Jim and Della?

A2. Complex Factual (2 marks)
Where did Della go after her decision? What did her actions show?

A3. Vocabulary (2 marks)
Find words from the passage that mean: (i) To decrease in value (ii) A waterfall

A4. Grammar (2 marks)
Do as directed:
(i) It reached below her knee. (Add a question tag)
(ii) She did it up again nervously and quickly. (Rewrite using 'not only... but also')

A5. Personal Response (2 marks)
Della was willing to sacrifice her most prized possession for Jim. What is the greatest sacrifice you would make for someone you love?
answer:
A1. The two prized possessions were Jim's gold watch and Della's beautiful, long hair.

A2. After her decision, Della put on her old jacket and hat and went out to the street. Her quick and decisive actions, despite her initial hesitation and tears, showed her deep love for Jim and her determination to buy him a worthy Christmas gift, even if it meant sacrificing her most precious possession.

A3. (i) depreciate (ii) cascade

A4.
(i) It reached below her knee, didn't it?
(ii) She did it up again not only nervously but also quickly.

A5. For someone I love, like my parents, the greatest sacrifice I would make is my time and comfort. I would be willing to give up my hobbies or leisure time to help and support them in any way they need, because their happiness and well-being are the most important things to me.

text:
Language Study (Grammar)

Do as directed:

1. Della finished her cry and attended to her cheeks. (Rewrite as a simple sentence)

2. She had only $1.87 with which to buy Jim a present. (Identify the infinitive)

3. It was a beautiful salmon. (Make it exclamatory)

4. She had read a book of mine. (Change the voice)
answer:
1. After finishing her cry, Della attended to her cheeks.

2. The infinitive is 'to buy'.

3. What a beautiful salmon it was!

4. A book of mine had been read by her.

text: Explain the irony in the story 'The Gift of the Magi'. Why are Jim and Della called the 'Magi'?
answer:
The irony in the story is that both Jim and Della sacrifice their most treasured possessions to buy a Christmas gift for the other, but their gifts become useless. Della sells her beautiful hair to buy a platinum chain for Jim's watch, while Jim sells his watch to buy expensive combs for Della's hair. This is an example of situational irony.

They are called the 'Magi' because, like the wise men who brought precious gifts to the infant Jesus, Jim and Della gave the wisest gifts of all. Their gifts were not the material objects, but their selfless love and sacrifice for each other, which is the true spirit of Christmas.
